title: random ping and lag issues,
body:
the vast majority of the time i play league. i have zero connection issues.. constant 66 ms ping
no lag, im the first person on any team to load to 100%.

yet over the last few weeks, every so often i get a random game where my ping spikes really high for a few min

i have a constant 200-500 ms ping for about a 2-15 min duration of time.

then it randomly goes back to normal 66 ms ping as if nothing happened.

sometimes i get a random visual lag of a champing running. but mostly the issue is gone.

now because the duration of the high ping i have been about to trouble shoot a lot of it.

i have have my running processes.. closed background programs. everything... and from what i can tell. its not MY computer that is the issue.

there seems to be something else on the network using bandwidth

now over the past month my dad has been working from home.. and we got a roku, but those are really the only things that have changed, and my dad uses a VPN to work and i don't think that is the issue

is there a way i can figure out which device on my network is USING the bandwidth. so i can either disable that device or choose not to play a ranked game when that device is in use.

i know its on my network, not riots.. and i know it isn't MY computer.

i suspect it is our "roku" but is there anyway i can confirm this, other than just unplugging the roku?

is there a way to see which IP on my network is using our bandwidth?


this is a bad game 

http://i.imgur.com/fXnvvle.png


and this is a normal game
http://i.imgur.com/OmKVOXa.png

replies.body:
Hey SwiftKitten88,

First off, *fistbump* for doing your research into this issue and understanding the basics of how your connection is routed to the League servers and where issues may lie. Since you've used the [Connection Log Reader](https://support.riotgames.com/hc/en-us/articles/209765743-Connection-Troubleshooting-Log-Reader), I'll assume you've already worked through the basic networking steps listed in our [Connection Troubleshooting Guide.](https://support.riotgames.com/hc/en-us/articles/201752664-Troubleshooting-Connection-Issues)

To find where the core issues lies, I'd like you to run a few separate logs during a period where you're experiencing the high latency. The first log is a [netalyzr](https://support.riotgames.com/hc/en-us/articles/201752674#wq1), which gives an in-depth analysis of your network conditions at that exact moment. Don't post the results here, as the log shows your **real IP address** at the top. Simply copy and paste the abnormality notes at the top to a reply here.

The second log is a traceroute, which you can run using the [WinMTR](http://winmtr.net) application. After you start the app, plug in the IP 104.160.131.1 and run a trace for 5 minutes. After you've reached that time, export the results as a text and paste them here. This log doesn't list your real IP address, so nothing to worry about here. Let me know if you have any questions, thanks!

The first log is a [netalyzr](https://support.riotgames.com/hc/en-us/articles/201752674#wq1), which gives an in-depth analysis of your network conditions at that exact moment. Don't post the results here, as the log shows your **real IP address** at the top. Simply copy and paste the abnormality notes at the top to a reply here.
> 
> The second log is a traceroute, which you can run using the [WinMTR](http://winmtr.net) application. After you start the app, plug in the IP 104.160.131.1 and run a trace for 5 minutes. After you've reached that time, export the results as a text and paste them here. This log doesn't list your real IP address, so nothing to worry about here. Let me know if you have any questions, thanks!

it took a while for the issue to appear again so sorry of the delay. (although not having it makes it better for me )
http://i.imgur.com/1Ym547z.png

netnlyzr say:

> Major Abnormalities 
>     We received unexpected and possibly dangerous results when looking up important names 
> 
> Minor Aberrations
> –
> 
>     Certain TCP protocols are blocked in outbound traffic
>     The network latency was somewhat high
>     Certain TCP protocols are blocked in outbound traffic 
> 
> 
> The round-trip time (RTT) between your computer and our server is 330 ms, which is somewhat high. This may be due to a variety of factors, including distance between your computer and our server, a slow network link, or other network traffic.
> We recorded no packet loss between your system and our server.
> TCP connection setup latency (?): 110ms
> +
> Background measurement of network health (?): no transient outages
> +
> Network bandwidth (?): Upload 5.7 Mbit/s, Download 13 Mbit/s
> +
> Network buffer measurements (?): Note 
> 
> 
> 
> DNS lookups of popular domains (?): Warning
> –
> 
> One popular name has a significant anomaly. The ownership suggested by the reverse name lookup does not match our understanding of the original name. This could be caused by an error somewhere in the domain information, deliberate blocking or redirection of a site using DNS, or it could be that your ISP's DNS Server is acting as a DNS "Man-in-the-Middle".
> 
> We attempted to download HTTP content from the IP addresses that your ISP's DNS server returned to you for these names. Where the download succeeded, you can click on the IP address in the table below to download a compressed file containing an HTTP session transcript.
> 
> Note! The session content is potentially harmful to your computer when viewed in a browser, so use caution when examining it.
> 
> mail.live.com  	hotmail.co.jp (IP REMOVED)
> 
> 2 popular names have a moderate anomaly: we are unable to find a reverse name associated with the IP address provided by your ISP's DNS server, although we expected to find a name. This is most likely due to a slow responding DNS server. If you rerun Netalyzr and see this condition remain, it could be due to a misconfiguration on the part of the domain owner, deliberate blocking using DNS, or your DNS server could be misconfigured or enabling a Man-in-the-Middle attack.
> wireless.att.com
> www.yahoo.com

Thanks for sending that. It definitely looks like there may be issues in your route, due to the high latency to the netalyzr server. In order to confirm this, though, I'll need to see the results of a traceroute using [WinMTR](http://winmtr.net).

> [{quoted}](name=Targons Blade,realm=NA,application-id=osqw6G4M,discussion-id=0htFTM6e,comment-id=000000000000,timestamp=2016-08-25T17:13:02.990+0000)
>
> Thanks for sending that. It definitely looks like there may be issues in your route, due to the high latency to the netalyzr server. In order to confirm this, though, I'll need to see the results of a traceroute using [WinMTR](http://winmtr.net).

 and i only ran it for about 3 min

i did get some what looks like packet loss in a co-op vs ai game earlier today.. (looked like the bot was standing still then it teleported half a screen away)

next they i get high ping though i will run the WinMTR in game

Oof! There are definitely some issues along your route to the server. The first hop outside your network at **96.120.90.13** shows *8% packet loss*, and if you look in the first column after the IP address of each node, you'll see your packet loss continuously grow with each hop, hitting *a peak of 72%* **before** hitting our servers. 

This is definitely a sign there are issues along your route with your ISP infrastructure, and will require an investigation from their team to resolve. I recommend reaching out to their tier 2 tech support and providing this traceroute so they have a bit more context on where the issues may lie. 

Let me know if you have any additional questions.
